issue.title: Not running WebSocket on HotReloading
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Hot relaoding works, but without Neutralino API
```
Uncaught DOMException: Failed to construct 'WebSocket': The URL 'ws://localhost:undefined' is invalid.
    at a (http://localhost:3000/neutralino.js:1:580)
    at Object.e.init (http://localhost:3000/neutralino.js:1:11526)
    at http://localhost:3000/src/main.js?t=1653880987265:6:19
```
I think is something related to the port to websocket but I not find anything about in the docs.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. I follow the instructions in https://neutralino.js.org/docs/how-to/use-a-frontend-library/
2. But using Vue + Vite
3. When run `vite build && neu run` Websocket works but not hot reloading
4. When run `vite` + `neu run --frontend-lib-dev` hot relaoding works but not Websocket

**Expected behavior**
Work hot reloading e Neutralino API.

**Specifications**  
 - OS: Windows 10 x64
 - Neutralinojs version: v4.6.0
 - Neutralinojs client library version: v3.5.0
 - Neutralinojs CLI version: v9.3.1

**Additional context**
neutralino.config.json
```json
{
  "applicationId": "js.neutralino.zero",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "defaultMode": "window",
  "documentRoot": "/output",
  "url": "/",
  "enableServer": true,
  "enableNativeAPI": true,
  "nativeAllowList": [
    "app.*",
    "window.*"
  ],
  "modes": {
    "window": {
      "title": "myapp",
      "width": 800,
      "height": 500,
      "minWidth": 400,
      "minHeight": 200,
      "icon": "/output/icon.png"
    }
  },
  "cli": {
    "binaryName": "myapp",
    "resourcesPath": "/output",
    "extensionsPath": "/extensions/",
    "clientLibrary": "/public/neutralino.js",
    "binaryVersion": "4.6.0",
    "clientVersion": "3.5.0",
    "frontendLibrary": {
        "patchFile": "/output/index.html",
        "devUrl": "http://localhost:3000"
    }
  }
}
```
vite.config.js
```javascript
import { defineConfig } from 'vite'
import vue from '@vitejs/plugin-vue'

// https://vitejs.dev/config/
export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [vue()],
  build: {
    outDir: './output'
  },
})
```
neutralinojs.log
```
INFO 2022-05-30 00:53:56,683 Auth info was exported to ./.tmp/auth_info.json api\debug\debug.cpp:14 jbwanderley2@STFSAOC045831-L
```
/.tmp/auth_info.json
```json
{"accessToken":"Ovg9BLuujZi1b3vNgRu0x2wQGTSSG7SV4tgTCS3uGCw-wUNh","port":54428}
```

comment.body:
> Add `<script src="__neutralino_globals.js"></script>` in `index.html` file fixed the problem for me. The `neu` process will automatically know to serve the globals there.
> 
> NL_PORT as well as other globals are sent to the browser window via `__neutralino_globals.js`. After a few tests, I fount it out how it works:
> 
> 1. When you run in "HMR" mode, `neu run --frontend-lib-dev`, the `neu` process searches the html file `cli.frontendLibrary.patchFile` for `<script src="(somepath)__neutralino_globals.js"></script>` and modify it into `<script src="http://localhost:(anotherport)/(somepath)__neutralino_globals.js"></script>`.  The program then host the globals there. Notice `(anotherport)` is different from other assets. If you force to quit in "HMR" mode `neu run --frontend-lib-dev`, like ctrl+C at neu cli command line, the restoration will not happen and a broken `index.html` file will be left there.
> 2. When you run `neu run`, the `neu` process  serve `__neutralino_globals.js` at the same port from other static assets. So no port replacement would happen.

How to quit HMR mode without ctrl+c?

issue.title: [RFC] Embed resources.neu into binary to get a real “single-file” app
issue.body:
## Intro

I'd like to help making Neutralino a real **single-file** app, so this issue is to share my progresses and get your feedbacks/suggestions 😉.

Making Neutralino a single-file app actually requires two steps:

1. (**Win64 only**) stop using WebView2Loader.dll library
2. (**all supported platforms**) embed the external `resources.neu` file into Neutralino binary

Step 1 was done by linking **statically** to WebView2LoaderStatic.lib (see my PR [here](https://github.com/neutralinojs/neutralinojs/pull/1109) and [here](https://github.com/neutralinojs/neutralinojs/issues/898)); it should be available in next release.

Now step 2...

## "resources.neu" embedding

To get a single-file app we must not only be able to prepare a binary that contains all of the files it needs at runtime, but also satisfy these requirements:

- be able to embed `resources.neu` to a **pre-built** binary: Neutralino is not re-built from sources each time, and this is a great feature because we don't need toolchains for each supported platform... This behavior must be preserved!
- Neutralino must be able to access the embedded `resources.neu` content at runtime **WITHOUT** extracting it. Extracting content to a temp directory each time the application is started is a waste of time and resources, and it pollutes user OSs.
- bundling must be optional, so it should still be possible to distribute a single (shared) `resources.neu` with all platform binaries, or run multiple `resources.neu` apps with the same binary (using `--path` parameter)

## Windows: PE (portable excutable)

Windows [PE executables](https://www.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_Executable) natively support **resources**, which can be added at compile time or added/changed post-build (by a PE resource editor tool).

PE resources can be:

- application metadata (version, description, author, copyright, digital signature)
- binary icon(s) (shown by Windows File Explorer)
- any other file content (like our `resources.neu` archive)

Pros of Win PE resources:

- can be added/changed not only at build-time but also **post-build**
- can be **retrieved by name**, so its easy for Neutralino to test if they're available or not and fallback to default (current) behavior
- can be accessed directly with a **memory-mapper pointer**, no need to extract them

Our final Neutralino application (not the Neutralino binary itself) is built by `neutralino-cli` (Node.js), so we need a cross-platform tool able to add Win64 resources to the downloaded pre-built Win64 binary. It must be cross-platform because we must be able to build the same Neutralino application on/for all supported platforms.

## My Win64 implementation

I've started working on the Win64 platform, because it's the first one I need (see `embedded-resources` branch on my forks: [neutralinojs](https://github.com/nicorac/neutralinojs/tree/embedded-resources), [neutralinojs-cli](https://github.com/nicorac/neutralinojs-cli/tree/embedded-resources)).

My forked `neutralinojs` looks for an embedded `resources.neu` file and, if found, it loads the embedded one instead of the external file (no extraction, straight in-memory load).

My forked `neutralino-cli` builds the application as before and then (as an extra optional step) injects the `resources.neu` archive into Win64 binary using the great [resedit](https://www.npmjs.com/package/resedit) npm library.
That's the perfect tool for this, since it allows PE resources management on existing WinPE binaries... and it's cross-platform!

`resedit` also gives an **additional feature** out-of-the-box: WinPE metadata management 🎉 \
It means we can also set Windows **icon, description, version, copyright**, ...

### Changes to neutralino.config.json

`neutralino.config.json` already contains a `version` field, so its value is used as `FileVersion` and `ProductVersion` WinPE version items. The other (optional) metadata values are loaded from the new `binaryMetadata` section:

```json
{
  "version": "1.1.0",
  ...
  "cli": {
    ...
    "binaryMetadata": {
      "name": "My single-file application",
      "description": "This web application was built with Neutralino",
      "copyright": "Copyright 2023 (github.com/nicorac)",
      "icon": "/icons/icon.ico",
      "embedResourcesArchive": true
    }
    ...
  }
}
```

> Notes:
>
> - `icon` MUST be an `*.ico` file
> - `embedResourcesArchive`: if true then the resulting `resources.neu` file will be injected into final WinPE binary

## Linux: ELF

There's nothing similar to WinPE "metadata" in **Linux ELF binaries**: no application icon, version, description... Binary version is usually retrieved through `--version` console parameter.

AFAIK the better way to add external data to an ELF binary is by using a custom section with a custom name (not starting with a dot). If this is the way to go, we need an npm library that could do this "injection" post-build (I haven't searched it yet...).

## MacOS

I have near-to-no experience with this OS, sorry 🙄

## References

These are some of the already existing issues on the same subject:

- [Single Executable](https://github.com/neutralinojs/neutralinojs/issues/943)
- [Completely portable executables](https://github.com/neutralinojs/neutralinojs/issues/789)
- [Single binary](https://github.com/neutralinojs/neutralinojs/issues/592)
- [Introduce build tool like electron-packager and nodebob](https://github.com/neutralinojs/neutralinojs/issues/127)

## Conclusions

Sorry for the long post. I'm all ears for your comments/suggestions/criticisms (be polite, please 😉).

comment.body: For x64 appimages [this project is](https://github.com/appvoid/synth) what you are looking for

issue.title: Recursive filesystem API
issue.body:
Requesting
1. Recursively create a directory (eg creating `thing1/thing2` creates all required things)
2. Recursively delete a directory (eg deleting `thing` deletes the whole directory even if it has stuff)

I can already do this with custom implementations but it's slower to do that. This is basic functionality that you can find in utilities like `rm` and `mkdir`.
